OK team. the devs have done great, but they cant do everything. sometimes they need us to do some of the groundwork. this was proven with multiplayer, and now with 64-bit.

I personally have no coding or modding experience, and i don't intend on doing that. but some of you are brilliant coders who enjoy doing that.

so. the purpose of this thread is for the tech minded people to discus how to unleash ksp's potential.

would it be possible for an individual or a group of individuals, to make ksp physics multi-threaded? or getting past any of the engines other limitations?

I thought a brainstorming thread would be good.

How do people test for multi-threaded performance?

If I open up resource monitor, I see a pretty equal distribution on both cores and their threads. This is why I ask. I am not tech savvy at all btw.
I just wonder if ksp uses instancing.If not, it would be a good way to solve the low performance problems with high part count vessels.

KSP IS multithreaded, but the Unity engine uses an old version of PhysX which can only run on one core. Squad can do nothing against performance bottlenecks that lie in the engine and neither can the community. I think Unity 5, which will come out in a few months, will have a newer version of PhysX, but there will be a lot of changes and updating it will take a lot of time.

and unitys windows 64bit was unworkable and a forum member fixed it, now its coming in .24 so there are ways to fix these engine problems.

Trying to 'fix' proprietary software is like trying to work on a car with the hood welded shut. You may make improvements, but they will always be awkward and second-rate. The best you can shoot for is to demonstrate something to squad (multiplayer, earth-sized planets, improved skybox, aerodynamics, active texture reduction, 64bit) and pray they take notice.

and unitys windows 64bit was unworkable and a forum member fixed it, now its coming in .24 so there are ways to fix these engine problems.

No, this forum member didn't fix the issues with Unity 64 bit, he just pointed out a way to use run KSP on windows in 64 bit and it turned out to be run more smoothly than expected. However, if I understand it correctly, KSP .24 will still run in 32 bit normally and there will be a second .exe included which will be 64 bit.

Neither squad nor any forum user can legally make any changes to the Unity engine.

Actually Squad has been working on 64 bit for a while, and the forum user found out how to use it, then Squad saw what was happening:

Hey Lilleman!

Just dropping by your thread to give you props. 64 bit development had been something we were working on on our spare time and behind the scenes for... a long time now! Like there was talk of small cleanup and fixes the day I was hired back in May 2013. (I've been here over a year now, wow) but due to the significantly higher expectations that the community has taken over our development, we felt 64 bit was still rather unstable and not really ready to be brought kicking and screaming into the public eye. Work continued on and off, with the release of 23.5 marking another 'yeah its not really showable yet'. Yet here you came! Enterprising and quite the explorer like most of our players seem to be, and you figured out how to access the work that had been done on the 64 bit client without having to wait for us to make it public.

This thread has been monitored constantly and quietly since you showed it to the world, and the response was far beyond our expectations. Thanks to this we've now grown confident enough to bring our work on the 64 bit version to the general public. Granted, it is very much at an experimental state and bugs in 32 bit will be prioritized, but consider this an eye opening experience and a thank you for helping us in seeing that sometimes we can show you guys the sausage production facilities and not have it end up with everyone hating hotdogs.

I think that people that want to try and help are already doing so, either officially or via mods. Unfortunately a few fundamental issues are in Unity itself, so unless you go work for them, we already have an amazing community.

This discussion would be more suitable under the development headings.
